options: Which embryological structure gives rise to the pinna?
subject: ENT
explanation:
The above image shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor. It is used in mastoidectomy procedures to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.
Shown below is Jansen’s self-retaining mastoid retractor.
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_306.jpeg]

options: A patient is incidentally noted to have the following finding. It is also present on the other ear. Which of the following is the cause for such abnormality?
Persistent opening of first branchial cleft
subject: ENT
explanation: The given instrument with an arrowed blade and angled shank is a myringotome. It is used for myringotomy.

options: When are reconstructive surgeries for congenital malformations of pinna usually performed?
subject: ENT
explanation:
Lempert’s trocar does not exist.
Option A: Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery.
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_307.jpeg]
Option B: Lempert’s endaural retractor is used for endaural approach to ear surgery. It has two lateral blades which retract the flaps and a third central blade with holes. The central blade retracts the temporalis muscle. The central blade can be fixed to the body of the retractor by its hole.
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_308.jpeg]
Option C: Lempert’s endaural speculum is used to spread open the meatus when giving the local injection or making an endaural incision.
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_309.jpeg]
Lempert’s incision is used in endaural approach. It consists of two parts:
Lempert I: It is a semicircular incision, made from 12 o’clock to 6 o’clock position in the posterior meatal wall at the bony-cartilaginous junction.
Lempert II: Starts from the first incision at 12 o’clock and then passes upwards in a curvilinear fashion between tragus and the crus of helix. It passes through the incisura terminalis and thus does not cut the cartilage.
Both mastoid and external canal surgery can be done.
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_310.jpeg]

options: Invagination of which of the following structures will form the external auditory meatus?
subject: ENT
explanation:
The above image is a MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker. During mastoid surgeries, one end is used to explore the air cells and the other end is used to curette the intervening septa and
granulations.
Note: MacEwan’s (suprameatal) triangle is an important landmark to locate the mastoid antrum in mastoid surgery. It is bounded by-
Temporal line
The posterosuperior segment of the bony external auditory canal
The line drawn as a tangent to the external canal

options: Examination of a child with otorrhea revealed two discharging sinuses. One was present on the floor of the left external auditory canal and the other on the left neck just below the angle of the mandible. Which of the following structures is abnormal here?
subject: ENT
explanation:
The image shows Luc’s forceps. It is not used in FESS. Luc’s forceps is used in:
Caldwell- Luc operation - to remove mucosa
Submucosal resection- to remove bone or cartilage
Polypectomy- to grasp and avulse polyps
To take a biopsy from the nose or throat

options: Which of the following structure develops from all three germ layers?
subject: ENT
explanation:
The image is of a Ballenger swivel knife. It is used in the removal of septal cartilage in SMR
(Submucosal resection) operation.
The blade of the knife revolves automatically and changes direction when cutting the cartilage anteroposteriorly downwards and posteroanteriorly. Different sizes of blades are present. It can be used to harvest septal cartilage as a graft for reconstruction.
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_311.jpeg]

options: Which of the structures given below forms the eustachian tube?
subject: ENT
explanation:
The procedure is proof puncture (antral lavage) which uses Tilley-Lichwitz trocar and cannula. They are used for the puncture of the lateral wall of the inferior meatus at a point 1.5-2.0cm from the anterior end of the inferior turbinate, near the attachment of concha with the lateral wall.
Tilley–Lichtwiz trocar and cannula:
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_312.jpeg]

options: Which of the following pharyngeal arches gives rise to malleus and incus?
subject: ENT
explanation:
The instrument is Rose’s sinus douching cannula. It is used in irrigation of the maxillary sinus, which should already have a nasoantral window due to intranasal antrostomy or Caldwell Luc operation. The direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside.
Note:
Trephination (also known as trepanning or burr holing) is a surgical intervention where a hole is drilled, incised or scraped into the skull using simple surgical tools. Trephination of frontal sinus is done for acute frontal sinusitis if there is persistence or exacerbation of pain or pyrexia in spite of medical treatment for 48 h or if the lid swelling is increasing and threatening orbital cellulitis.

options: Which of the following arches gives rise to the stapes?
subject: ENT
explanation:
The image is of a Digital audiometer.
An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing loss at that frequency. This is charted in the form of a graph
called an audiogram.
The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A–B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness.
Uses:
To measure the threshold of hearing of air and bone conduction
Helps to predict speech reception threshold
To diagnose the type of hearing loss and measure the degree
For the prescription of hearing aids
Helps to find the degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes
A record can be kept for future reference.

options: Which of the following attains adult size before birth?
subject: ENT
explanation:
The image is of a tympanometer. It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear.
It is based on a simple principle that when a sound strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.
By charting the compliance of the tympano-ossicular system against various pressure changes, different types of graphs called tympanograms are as follows:
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_313.jpeg]

options: Which of the following does not reach adult size at birth?
subject: ENT
explanation:
Tumour limited to both vocal cords with normal mobility can be classified as stage T1b. Treatment will include radiotherapy or transoral laser microsurgery. There is no indication for a total laryngectomy.
Total laryngectomy is indicated in:
All T4 lesions
Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement
Lesions of the posterior commissure
Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
Transglottic cancers with cord fixation.
It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.
Treatment of T3 cancers is controversial, open vertical hemilaryngectomy and more
extensive partial laryngectomies are used in carefully selected cases. Total laryngectomy or CRT is recommended for bulky T3 tumors or tumors not suitable for conservation laryngeal surgery.

options: An ENT surgeon has difficulty locating the mastoid antrum due to the presence of Korner's septum. Which of the following sutures is persistent in this case?
subject: ENT
explanation:
Among the given options, a patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility will be advised for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice. TNM staging in this patient is T1a.
Option A: TNM staging here is T2b and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first choice.
Option C: TNM staging here is T4a and the patient is advised for total laryngectomy as the first choice.
Option D: TNM staging here is T3 and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first choice.
TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002) Treatment of laryngeal cancers:
TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT: Chemotherapy; CRT: Chemoradiotherapy, TL: Total laryngectomy.

options: From which of the following structure does the saccule develop?
subject: ENT
explanation:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland.
The disadvantage of a high tracheostomy is subglottic stenosis at the level of the cricoid and perichondritis of the cricoid. However, in laryngeal carcinoma this would be a temporary measure as the definitive management is total laryngectomy.
Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea.
Functions:
Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
Allows positive pressure respiration
Allows administration of anesthesia Indications:
Respiratory obstruction due to
Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis)
Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
Neoplasms
Foreign bodies or edema
Bilateral abductor paralysis
Congenital anomalies
Retained secretions
Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
Painful cough
Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis
Instruments

Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)

Ballenger swivel knife

Tilley–Lichtwiz trocar

Question 9:
A 20-year-old woman has complaints of reduced hearing on her right side. You perform a diagnostic test using the following instrument. What is the name of this instrument?
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_25.jpeg, ENT_img_302.jpeg, ENT_img_303.jpeg, ENT_img_304.jpeg]

An objective diagnostic test is performed on a patient who complains of loss of hearing on his right side. The following instrument is used to perform this test. What is this instrument known as?
 [Image Reference: ENT_img_26.jpeg, ENT_img_305.jpeg]
Digital audiometer

Answer Key

options: From how many ossification centre(s) does the inner ear develop?
subject: ENT
explanation:
Surgical trauma is the most common cause of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.
The incidence of permanent RLN paralysis is approximately 1% to 1.5% for total thyroidectomy and less for near-total procedures.
Note: Previously, extra laryngeal malignancies had been the most common cause which included lung (50%), esophagus, thyroid, and larynx.

options: When does the fetus start hearing?
subject: ENT
explanation:
Ortner's syndrome is a rare cause of left (unilateral) recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy due to compression by enlarged cardiac structures such as the left atrium or pulmonary artery.
Causes of recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy:
Thyroid surgery
Neck trauma
Thyroid malignancy
Cervical lymphadenopathy.
Though the risk of bilateral nerve involvement is much less than unilateral, it is possible. Depending on whether the palsy is unilateral or bilateral, findings will differ.
Terminologies in vocal cord palsy:
Pure RLN palsy: abductor palsy (the only abductor, posterior cricoarytenoid is affected)
Pure SLN palsy: rare (only cricothyroid, one of the adductors and the main tensor is affected)
Complete paralysis: both SLN and RLN are involved.
